{{Good article}} {{EngvarB|date=December 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Tammy Abraham | image = Tammy Abraham 20160511.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Abraham warming up for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2016 | fullname = Kevin Oghenetega Tamaraebi Bakumo-Abraham{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/tammy-abrahamm/372977/ |title=T. Abraham: Summary |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=6 August 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|10|2|df=y}}{{cite web |url=https://www.11v11.com/players/tammy-abraham-252087/ |title=Tammy Abraham |website=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=11 November 2017}} | birth_place = [[Camberwell]], London, England | height = {{convert|1.90|m|order=flip}} | position = [[Forward (association football)#Striker|Striker]] | currentclub = [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]
(on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]) | clubnumber = 18 | youthyears1 = 2004–2016 | youthclubs1 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | years1 = 2016– | clubs1 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | caps1 = 2 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2016–2017 | clubs2 = → [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] (loan) | caps2 = 41 | goals2 = 23 | years3 = 2017–2018 | clubs3 = → [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] (loan) | caps3 = 31 | goals3 = 5 | years4 = 2018– | clubs4 = → [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] (loan) | caps4 = 29 | goals4 = 21 | nationalyears1 = 2014–2015 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] | nationalcaps1 = 5 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalyears2 = 2015–2016 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 14 | nationalgoals2 = 5 | nationalyears3 = 2016– | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 22 | nationalgoals3 = 8 | nationalyears4 = 2017– | nationalteam4 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps4 = 2 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | club-update = 23:12, 2 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 17:56, 9 February 2019 (UTC) }} '''Kevin Oghenetega Tamaraebi Bakumo-Abraham''' (born 2 October 1997), known as '''Tammy Abraham''', is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] of the [[EFL Championship|Championship]], on [[loan (sports)|loan]] from {{English football updater|Chelsea}} club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and the [[England national football team|English national team]]. An academy graduate of Chelsea, Abraham made his senior debut for the club in 2016 before enjoying [[Loan (sports)|loan]] spells with Championship club [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] and fellow [[Premier League]] team [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]]. During his time with the former, he won the club's Player of the Season and Young Player of the Season awards and was their top goalscorer, becoming the first player ever to do so in a single season. Formerly an [[England national youth football team|England youth international]], Abraham represented the nation from [[England national under-18 football team|under-18 level]], and featured at the [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] in Poland. He made his senior debut in November 2017. ==Club career== ===Chelsea=== ====Early career==== [[File:Marcin Wasilewski, Tammy Abraham.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Abraham (right) making his home debut for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2016]] Abraham joined Chelsea at under-8 level and progressed through the club's academy system.{{cite web |url=https://www.chelseafc.com/teams/development-squad/under-21s/u21-player-profiles/tammy-abraham.html |title=Tammy Abraham |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |accessdate=11 May 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160511120030/https://www.chelseafc.com/teams/development-squad/under-21s/u21-player-profiles/tammy-abraham.html |archivedate=11 May 2016}} He was part of the Chelsea youth team which recorded consecutive triumphs in both the [[UEFA Youth League]] and the [[FA Youth Cup]] in 2015 and 2016. In the [[2015–16 UEFA Youth League|2015–16 edition]] of the UEFA Youth League, Abraham pitched in with a return of eight goals in nine matches, making him the tournament's second highest goal scorer behind [[Roberto Núñez Mañas|Roberto Núñez]].{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefayouthleague/news/newsid=2354579.html |title=Atlético Madrid's Nuñez takes top scorer honours |publisher=UEFA |date=18 April 2016 |accessdate=11 November 2017}} He carried his form into the FA Youth Cup and netted the winning goal in Chelsea's victory over [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in the final in April.{{cite news |last=Belshaw |first=George (27 April 2016) |url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/04/27/chelseas-tammy-abraham-scores-brilliant-header-as-blues-bag-third-consecutive-fa-youth-cup-title-v-manchester-city-5846162/ |title=Chelsea's Tammy Abraham scores brilliant header as Blues bag third consecutive FA Youth Cup title v Manchester City |newspaper=Metro |location=London |accessdate=11 May 2016}} During the 2014–15 and 2015–16 seasons, Abraham scored 74 goals in 98 matches across all competitions for Chelsea's various youth teams.{{cite news |last=Kinsella |first=Nizaar (15 May 2016) |url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/85/england/2016/05/15/23570252/chelsea-finally-gives-youth-a-chance-but-will-conte-follow |title=Chelsea finally gives youth a chance, but will Conte follow suit? |publisher=Goal.com |accessdate=17 May 2016}} His form at youth level caught the attention of interim [[Manager (association football)|manager]] [[Guus Hiddink]] who invited him to train with the senior team at the back end of the [[2015–16 Premier League|2015–16]] season.{{cite news |last=Deniran-Alleyne |first=Tashan (9 May 2016) |url=http://www.squawka.com/news/tammy-abraham-training-with-chelseas-first-team-report/665894 |title=Tammy Abraham training with Chelsea's first-team – report |website=Squawka |accessdate=12 May 2016}} On 11 May 2016, Hiddink handed Abraham his Chelsea debut in a 1–1 [[Premier League]] draw with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], bringing him on to replace [[Bertrand Traoré]] in the 74th minute.{{cite web |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/how-tammy-abraham-capitalised-on-antonio-conte-s-tactical-advice-to-fire-his-way-into-chelsea-s-a3424506.html |title=How Tammy Abraham capitalised on Antonio Conte's tactical advice to fire his way into Chelsea's first team plans |newspaper=London Evening Standard |last=Bhardwaj |first=Vaishali |date=20 December 2016 |accessdate=11 November 2017}} Abraham then made his home debut at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] the following week, once again coming on as a second-half [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for Traoré in a 1–1 draw with newly-crowned Premier League Champions [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]. ====Loan to Bristol City==== [[File:Referee James Linington feels Tammy Abraham's pain (28712920603).jpg|thumb|upright|Abraham (right) playing for [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] in 2016]] On 5 August 2016, Abraham signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on a season-long [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from Chelsea.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36985799 |title=Tammy Abraham: Bristol City sign Chelsea forward on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 August 2016 |accessdate=5 August 2016}} He made his debut for the club the following day, coming off the bench for fellow debutant [[Josh Brownhill]] to score City's first goal in a 2–1 come-from-behind win over [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]], although the goal was later credited to [[Hörður Björgvin Magnússon|Hörður Magnússon]] instead.{{cite web |url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2016/09/29/tammy-abraham-three-performances-that-show-why-striker-is-pfa-pl/ |title=Tammy Abraham: Three performances that show why striker is PFA Player of the Month |website=HITC |last=Feehan |first=Katie |date=29 September 2016 |accessdate=2 January 2017}} He started in his second game and scored the only goal of the match in a 1–0 win over [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], helping Bristol City advance to the Second Round of the [[2016–17 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36949819 |title=Tammy Abraham scored his second goal in two Bristol City games |date=9 August 2016 |accessdate=2 January 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport}} The following week, on 13 August, he scored his first professional brace in a 2–1 victory over newly promoted [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]], including the last-minute winner.{{Cite news |title=Burton Albion 1–2 Bristol City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36993972 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 August 2016 |accessdate=13 August 2016}} In September, Abraham scored his second brace against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]], although Bristol City ultimately lost 3–2.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37282509 |title=Sheffield Wednesday 3–2 Bristol City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2016 |accessdate=30 September 2016}} He scored a further two goals during the month which saw him named Championship Player of the Month for September.{{cite news |last=Rathborn |first=Jack (29 September 2016) |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/tammy-abraham-wins-championship-player-8938878 |title=Tammy Abraham wins Championship Player of the Month as Bristol City boss jokes over permanent move |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |accessdate=30 September 2016}} He was also awarded the [[EFL Young Player of the Month]] award for September.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37755928 |last=Garry |first=Tom |title=Tammy Abraham: EFL Young Player award for Bristol City's on-loan Chelsea striker |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 October 2016 |accessdate=25 October 2016}} On 31 January 2017, Abraham scored his 16th Championship goal in a 2–2 draw against Sheffield Wednesday, which saw him break the record of former [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] striker [[Moussa Dembélé (French footballer)|Moussa Dembélé]] for the most goals scored by a teenager since the beginning of the Football League Championship era.{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-za/news/tammy-abraham-is-the-record-breaking-teenager-the-future-of/wqygm5ptmqhi1dwhcjlqbono2 |title=Tammy Abraham: Is the record-breaking teenager the future of Chelsea? |publisher=Goal.com |date=20 March 2017 |accessdate=11 November 2017}} Abraham ended the season with 23 goals to his name, second only to [[Chris Wood (footballer, born 1991)|Chris Wood]] of [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]], as City completed the campaign in 17th position, thereby avoiding relegation.{{cite news |url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/05/07/bristol-city-fans-gutted-to-see-chelsea-loan-star-tammy-abraham-play-final-game-for-club-6621079/ |title=Bristol City fans gutted to see Chelsea loan star Tammy Abraham play final game for club |newspaper=Metro |location=London |last=Barry |first=Coral |date=7 May 2017 |accessdate=7 May 2017}} His performances throughout the season also earned him Bristol City's Player of the Year, Young Player of the Year and Top Goalscorer awards. In doing so, he became the first ever player to earn all three awards in the same season.{{cite web |url=https://www.bcfc.co.uk/news/abraham-makes-history-with-triple-crown-of-awards/ |title=Abraham makes history with triple crown of awards |publisher=Bristol City F.C. |last=Baker |first=Adam |date=7 May 2017 |accessdate=8 May 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180103233351/https://www.bcfc.co.uk/news/abraham-makes-history-with-triple-crown-of-awards/ |archivedate=3 January 2018}} ====Loan to Swansea City==== [[File:06 Tammy Abraham, Samuel Clucas & Tom Carroll IMG 3741 (24212924278).jpg|thumb|upright|Abraham celebrating a [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] goal in 2017]] On 4 July 2017, Chelsea announced that Abraham had signed a new five-year contract with the club and later that day he joined fellow Premier League club [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] on a season-long loan.{{cite web |url=http://kwese.espn.com/football/story/3150431/chelsea-striker-tammy-abraham-joins-swansea-on-season-long-loan |title=Chelsea striker Tammy Abraham joins Swansea on season-long loan |publisher=ESPN |last=Twomey |first=Liam |date=4 July 2017 |accessdate=4 July 2017}} He made his debut for the club on 12 August, starting in a 0–0 draw with [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/swansea-city-team-news-tammy-13467927 |title=Swansea City team news: Tammy Abraham handed full debut at Southampton as Paul Clement opts to leave Roque Mesa on the bench |website=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |last=Gwilym |first=Andrew |date=12 August 2017 |accessdate=12 August 2017}} Ten days later, he scored his first competitive goal in a 4–1 League Cup win over [[EFL League One|League One]] team [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] before scoring his first Premier League goal in his next match, opening the scoring in a 2–0 victory over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{cite web |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/mk-dons-1-swansea-city-13514869 |title=MK Dons 1 Swansea City 4: Leroy Fer at the double and Tammy Abraham opens his account as Swans cruise through in Carabao Cup |website=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |last=Gwilym |first=Andrew |date=22 August 2017 |accessdate=22 August 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/aug/26/crystal-palace-swansea-city-premier-league-match-report |title=Gloom for Crystal Palace after Tammy Abraham inspires Swansea to easy win |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |last=Nakrani |first=Sachin |date=26 August 2017 |accessdate=26 August 2017}} On 14 October 2017, he scored his first brace for his club in a 2–0 win over newly promoted [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] which secured Swansea their first home win of the season.{{cite web |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/swansea-city-v-huddersfield-town-13761352 |title=Tammy Abraham's brace gives Swans 2–0 victory in Premier League clash at the Liberty Stadium |website=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |last=Esonu |first=Emmanuel |date=16 October 2017 |accessdate=16 October 2017}} Both club and player struggled for form thereafter, however, and by the end of the year Abraham had failed to add to his goal tally.{{cite web |url=https://www.eurosport.com/football/premier-league/2017-2018/premier-league-preview-manchester-united-take-on-burnley_sto6456844/story.shtml |title=Premier League preview: Who will end 2017 on a high? |website=Eurosport |last=Netherton |first=Alexander |date=29 December 2017 |accessdate=4 January 2018}} On 6 February 2018, having gone 825 minutes without a goal, Abraham returned to the scoresheet when he netted twice and [[Assist (football)|assisted]] a further two in an 8–1 [[FA Cup]] Fourth Round replay win over [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]].{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-za/news/tammy-abraham-delighted-to-be-back-with-the-goals/vpfsb910obuh1ewsmlgb9rblg |title=Tammy Abraham delighted to be 'back with the goals' |website=Goal |last=Olasoji |first=Tolu |date=6 February 2018 |accessdate=7 February 2018}} The result was also Swansea's biggest ever win in the competition.{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/34651/11239534/swansea-8-1-notts-county-hosts-record-biggest-ever-fa-cup-win |title=Swansea 8–1 Notts County: Hosts record biggest-ever FA Cup win |website=SkySports |date=7 February 2018 |accessdate=10 February 2018}} On 7 April, he scored his first league goal since his double in October. His goal earned Swansea a late draw against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Brom]] and edged the club a point closer to safety from the relegation zone, though they were ultimately relegated on the final day of the season following a defeat to [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/04/07/west-brom-denied-long-awaited-win-late-tammy-abraham-leveller/ |title=West Brom denied long-awaited win by late Tammy Abraham leveller for Swansea |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |last=Culley |first=Jon |date=7 April 2018 |accessdate=7 April 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2018/05/13/swansea-stoke-swans-relegation-confirmed-potters-bow-out-win |title=Swansea Relegation Confirmed as Stoke City Bows Out With Win |date=13 May 2018 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} Abraham scored eight goals in 39 appearances across all competitions during his loan spell with the club.{{soccerbase season|91497|2017|accessdate=12 August 2018}} ====Loan to Aston Villa==== Following Abraham's return from loan at Swansea, new Chelsea manager [[Maurizio Sarri]] indicated that he planned to keep him at Chelsea and included him in the squad for the club's [[FA Community Shield|Community Shield]] defeat to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].{{cite news |url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/1000979/Chelsea-transfer-news-Maurizio-Sarri-Tammy-Abraham-gossip-rumours |title=Chelsea transfer news: Maurizio Sarri makes plan for Blues youngster Tammy Abraham |newspaper=Daily Express |last=Malam |first=Charlie |date=9 August 2018 |accessdate=31 August 2018}} On 31 August, however, Abraham was sent out on loan once again, returning to the Championship to sign for [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] for the remainder of the season.{{cite web |title=Tammy Abraham: Aston Villa sign Chelsea forward on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45371400 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=31 August 2018 |date=31 August 2018}} He made his debut for the club on 15 September, starting in a 1–1 draw with [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], and scored on his home debut four days later in a 2–0 win over [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]].{{cite news |url=http://www.goal.com/en-za/news/he-has-done-very-well-steve-bruce-on-tammy-abrahams-aston/n3rpddbem6b911qfs9fhlp5st |title=‘He has done very well’ – Steve Bruce on Tammy Abraham's Aston Villa debut |publisher=Goal |last=Olasoji |first=Tolu |date=16 September 2018 |accessdate=16 September 2018}}{{cite news |url=http://www.goal.com/en-za/news/aston-villa-coach-bruce-hail-abraham-bolasie-after/1rfhu36kxxvn140cjgezr0pxt |title=Aston Villa coach Bruce hail Abraham, Bolasie after goalscoring home debuts |publisher=Goal |last=Olasoji |first=Tolu |date=19 September 2018 |accessdate=20 September 2018}} On 28 November, he scored four goals in a 5–5 draw with [[Nottingham Forest F.C|Nottingham Forest]] in the league; the first time a draw of that score had ever been played out to at [[Villa Park]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/nov/28/tammy-abraham-scores-four-as-aston-villa-draw-5-5-with-nottingham-forest |title=Tammy Abraham scores four as Aston Villa draw 5–5 with Nottingham Forest |newspaper=The Guardian |date=28 November 2018 |accessdate=29 November 2018}} In doing so, he became the first Aston Villa player to score four goals in a single match in the 21st century.{{cite news |url=https://www.goal.com/en-za/news/outstanding-tammy-abraham-named-championship-player-of-the/27qgcnwdwjmx1ku2mwjnxpv0s |title=Outstanding Tammy Abraham named Championship Player of the Month |publisher=Goal |last=Taiwo|first=Taiye |date=7 December 2018 |accessdate=29 December 2018}} He was later named Championship Player of the Month for November after scoring six goals in four appearances for the month. By the turn of the year, Abraham had scored 16 goals in 20 appearances and was the joint-top goalscorer in the league. His strong form sparked speculation that he would be recalled by Chelsea, who retained the option until 14 January 2018, given the club's own goal scoring troubles.{{cite news|url=https://www.goal.com/en-za/news/recalling-tammy-abraham-would-confirm-chelsea/1jwwy9i1o3nir1y1tcvge9e95i|title=Recalling Tammy Abraham would confirm Chelsea thoughtlessness|publisher=Goal|last=Omidiora|first=Seye|date=29 December 2018|accessdate=5 January 2019}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2019/01/03/chelsea-decide-tammy-abrahams-future-january-14/|title=Chelsea to decide on Tammy Abraham's future by January 14|publisher=The Telegraph|last=Percy|first=John|date=3 January 2019|accessdate=5 January 2019}} It later became apparent that Premier League side [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] had also made an approach for his signature, although [[FIFA]]'s rules prohibiting a player from representing three clubs in a season cast doubt over any potential move.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/wolves-transfer-news-tammy-abraham-latest-chelsea-aston-villa-premier-league-fifa-a8711736.html|title=Wolves remain confident of signing Tammy Abraham from Chelsea despite possible complications|publisher=The Independent|last=Mashiter|first=Nick|date=4 January 2019|accessdate=5 January 2019}} Following a week of media speculation surrounding his future, Abraham rejected a loan move to Wolves in favour of staying with Villa for the remainder of the season.{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/2019/jan/08/tammy-abraham-snubs-wolves-loan-move-stay-aston-villa-transfer-window-football|title=Tammy Abraham snubs Wolves loan to stay and help Villa promotion push|publisher=The Guardian|date=9 January 2019|accessdate=9 January 2019|last=James|first=Stuart}}{{cite news|url=https://www.goal.com/en-za/news/i-felt-here-was-home-tammy-abraham-opens-up-on-aston-villa/1c1f1dnkdwea212yu27si79zxs|title='I felt here was home' - Tammy Abraham opens up on Aston Villa decision|publisher=Goal|last=Taiwo|first=Taiye|date=4 February 2019|accessdate=14 February 2019}} On 26 January, he scored a brace in a 2–1 win over [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich]] and in doing so became the first player since [[Pongo Waring]] in 1933 to score in seven consecutive home games for the club.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/46928848|title=Aston Villa 2–1 Ipswich|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 January 2019|accessdate=27 January 2019}} The following month, he became the first player since [[Peter Withe]] in 1981 to score 20 goals for the club in a single season when he scored in a 3–3 come–from–behind draw with [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]].{{cite news|url=https://www.goal.com/en-za/news/20-goal-tammy-abraham-backed-to-lead-aston-villas-promotion/1jdom91itsepy1r9iwdjr5bbx4|title=20-goal Tammy Abraham backed to lead Aston Villa’s promotion push|publisher=Goal|last=Taiwo|first=Taiye|date=13 February 2019|accessdate=14 February 2019}} ==International career== Despite being an [[England national youth football team|England youth international]], and having featured in non-competitive fixtures for the senior team, Abraham remains eligible to represent [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] through his paternal lineage and was in the past sounded out by the Nigerian Football Association.{{cite news |last=Emmanuel |first=Ifeanyi (7 July 2016) |url=http://www.allnigeriasoccer.com/read_news.php?nid=19669 |title=Officials Hold Talks With Chelsea Striker Tammy Abraham, Dad Over Playing For Nigeria |website=All Nigeria Soccer |accessdate=28 August 2016}} Abraham's father is close friends with [[Nigeria Football Federation]] President, [[Amaju Pinnick]] and on 21 September 2017, Pinnick claimed that Abraham had switched his allegiance to Nigeria. Abraham issued a statement the same day denying the claim and reaffirming his availability for England selection.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/21/tammy-abraham-chelsea-nigeria-england-switch |title=Chelsea's Tammy Abraham denies he is set to switch allegiance to Nigeria |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |last=Aarons |first=Ed |date=21 September 2017 |accessdate=28 September 2017}} Upon receiving his first England call-up in November 2017, Abraham stated that there was never any prospect of him choosing to play for Nigeria.{{cite web |url=http://kwese.espn.com/football/swansea-city/story/3262129/swansea-forward-tammy-abraham-firmly-committed-to-england |title=Swansea forward Tammy Abraham firmly committed to England |publisher=ESPN |last=Miller |first=Nick |date=7 November 2017 |accessdate=10 November 2017}} ===Youth=== Abraham has represented England at both [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]] and [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] level. He scored his first goals at age group level for England in March 2015, netting a brace as England U18 defeated [[Switzerland national under-18 football team|Switzerland]] 6–1.{{cite web |last=Stonehouse |first=Gary |date=28 March 2015 |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2015/mar/tammy-abraham-keep-on-scoring-england-u18s-v-switzerland-280315 |title=Tammy Abraham: 'I've just got to keep on scoring' |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=12 June 2016}} Later that year, while representing the U19 team in a [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly]] against [[Japan national under-19 football team|Japan]], Abraham and teammate [[Patrick Roberts]] played a game of [[rock–paper–scissors]] on the pitch to decide who would take a penalty. Abraham was triumphant but missed the resultant spot-kick. Just a minute later, however, Roberts assisted Abraham for the second goal of the match, which ultimately ended 5–1 in England's favour.{{cite news |last=Olver |first=Tom (15 November 2015) |url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/11/15/tammy-abraham-and-patrick-roberts-play-rock-paper-scissors-to-decide-penalty-taker-for-england-under-19s-5503761/ |title=Tammy Abraham and Patrick Roberts play rock, paper, scissors to decide penalty taker for England Under-19s |newspaper=Metro |location=London |accessdate=12 June 2016}} [[File:2017083201737 2017-03-24 Fussball U21 Deutschland vs England - Sven - 1D X - 0230 - DV3P6556 mod.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Abraham playing for [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] in 2017]] On 6 July 2016, Abraham was one of four Chelsea players named in [[Aidy Boothroyd]]'s [[2016 UEFA European Under-19 Championship squads#England|squad]] for the [[UEFA European Under-19 Championship|U19 European Championship]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/jul/06/under-19s-euro-squad-named-060716 |title=England U19s squad named for Euros Challenge |publisher=The Football Association |last=Veevers |first=Nicholas |date=7 July 2016 |accessdate=12 November 2017}} He featured in three out of four matches as England were eliminated by [[Italy national under-19 football team|Italy]] in the [[semi-final]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/jul/21/italy-report-210716 |title=England U-19s' Euro dreams ended by Italy in semi-final |publisher=The Football Association |date=21 July 2016 |accessdate=12 November 2017}} Abraham also received his first [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] call-up on 29 September 2016. He made his first appearance for the team on 6 October, coming on as a substitute with eight minutes remaining against [[Kazakhstan national under-21 football team|Kazakhstan]] in a qualifier for the U21 European Championships to help England to a 1–0 victory which secured the nation's progression to the tournament proper. He made his full debut for the U21s in their final group stage match against [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national under-21 football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] and netted twice in a 5–0 victory for England.{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/england-u21-vs-bosnia-and-herzegovina-u21/338970 |title=England U21s 5–0 Bosnia-Herzegovina U21s: Tammy Abraham nets brace in convincing win |publisher=Sky Sports |last=Yew |first=Oliver |date=11 October 2016 |accessdate=12 November 2017}} The following year, he was named in the [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship squads#England|England squad]] for the [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] in Poland.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/jun/05/england-u21s-euro-squad-selected-050617 |title=U21's Euros Squad Selected |publisher=The Football Association |date=5 June 2017 |accessdate=20 June 2017 |last=Veevers |first=Nicholas}} He scored his first, and only goal for the tournament in the semi-final against [[Germany national under-21 football team|Germany]]. England ultimately lost the match after a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shoot-out]], with Abraham one of the players who missed his spot-kick.{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11668/10934481/tammy-abraham-to-swansea-why-the-chelsea-striker-will-be-a-success |title=Tammy Abraham to Swansea: Why the Chelsea striker will be a success |publisher=Sky Sports |last=Bate |first=Adam |date=4 July 2017 |accessdate=4 July 2017}} On 18 May 2018, having been omitted from [[2018 FIFA World Cup squads#England|England's squad]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], Abraham was recalled to the [[2018 Toulon Tournament squads#England|under-20 side]] for the [[Toulon Tournament]] in France where they had been drawn in a group alongside [[Qatar national under-20 football team|Qatar]], China and [[Mexico national under-20 football team|Mexico]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-44154538 |title=How I found out about my England call-up |publisher=BBC |date=17 May 2018 |accessdate=18 May 2018}}{{cite web |publisher=The Football Association |date=18 May 2018 |accessdate=18 May 2018 |title=England U21s head to Maurice Revello Tournament in Toulon with a 20-man squad |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2018/may/18/england-u21s-squad-named-for-toulon-180518}} On 27 May, England opened their title defence with a 2–1 win over China in which Abraham scored the winning goal.{{cite news |title=Tammy Abraham rescues England in Toulon opener |first=Matt |last=Reed |date=27 May 2018 |accessdate=30 May 2018 |publisher=NBC Sports |url=https://soccer.nbcsports.com/2018/05/27/tammy-abraham-rescues-england-in-toulon-opener/}} He did not feature in the subsequent match against Mexico but returned to score in a 4–0 win over Qatar which saw England qualify for the semi-finals where they were drawn against [[Scotland national under-20 football team|Scotland]].{{cite news |title=Toulon Tournament: England and Mexico play out draw in France |date=29 May 2018 |accessdate=30 May 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44297181}}{{cite news |url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2779012-england-fail-to-secure-automatic-toulon-qualification-despite-big-win-over-qatar |title=England Fail to Secure Automatic Toulon Qualification Despite Big Win over Qatar |publisher=Bleacher Report |last=Jones |first=Matt |date=1 June 2018 |accessdate=6 June 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/06/05/england-u21-manager-says-semi-final-spot-toulon-tournament-minimum/ |title=England U21 manager says semi-final spot at Toulon Tournament is minimum target, but warns against complacency |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |last=Edwards |first=Luke |date=5 June 2018 |accessdate=6 June 2018}} Abraham was only used as a late substitute as England defeated Scotland but was selected to start in the final where they met Mexico. There he was unlucky not to score, hitting the post in the second half, but helped England claim their third successive title with a 2–1 win.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44426516 |title=Toulon Tournament: England U21s secure third successive title with 2–1 win over Mexico |publisher=BBC |last=O'Keefe |first=Greg |date=9 June 2018 |accessdate=12 June 2018}} ===Senior=== On 2 November 2017, Abraham was one of three uncapped players called up to the senior [[England national football team|England]] team for [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendlies]] against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]].{{cite web |url=http://kwese.espn.com/football/england/story/3255581/joe-gomez-ruben-loftus-cheek-and-tammy-abraham-get-england-call-ups |title=Joe Gomez, Ruben Loftus-Cheek and Tammy Abraham get England call-ups |publisher=ESPN |date=2 November 2017 |accessdate=2 November 2017}}{{cite web |title=England: Tammy Abraham, Joe Gomez & Ruben Loftus-Cheek called up |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41848591 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 November 2017 |date=2 November 2017}} He made his debut against the former on 10 November, starting in a 0–0 draw at [[Wembley Stadium]].{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=England 0–0 Germany |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41854505 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 November 2017 |accessdate=11 November 2017}} ==Personal life== Abraham was born in [[Camberwell]], London. He has a younger brother, Timmy, who is also a footballer and plays in the academy system at [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].{{cite news |url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2017/05/25/fulham-sign-chelsea-striker-tammy-abrahams-brother-timmy |title=Timmy Abraham, brother of Chelsea foward [sic] Tammy |newspaper=HITC |location=London |last=Brown |first=Christian |date=25 May 2017 |accessdate=27 August 2017}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/chelsea-stars-younger-brother-joins-13089934 |title=Chelsea star's younger brother joins Fulham after impressing on trial |website=Get West London |last=O'Donovan |first=Ryan |date=25 May 2017 |accessdate=9 August 2017}} In January 2017, Abraham was involved in a motor vehicle accident while on loan at Bristol City. At the time of the accident he was alleged to have been driving without a licence or insurance, and was summoned to court as a result. He later obtained his licence, passing the test in March of the same year.{{cite news |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/bristol-news/tammy-abraham-passes-driving-test-10765 |title=Tammy Abraham
